data.meta_desc: Big Mac in USA $4.80 Big Mac in Denmark $5.15 McDonalds worker salary in USA $7.25 McDonalds worker salary in Denmark $22 100% true - BUT It's not because of minimumwage Denmark along a few other European countries DO NOT have ANY minimum wage. Instead there's laws implemented that state that you can not underpay workers. But how do you define underpaid without minimum Well minimum wage state what is legal to pay as such most employers will happily excuse them by this (there's even lobby to get a minimum wage in Denmark *sigh*). Instead Danish workers are unionised in a scale US can't image. 60-70% 80% in negotiation times. If one is paid 50% less than colegues or comparable posistion outside a company a court will propably rule in favour of the worker. Unions set the "minimum wage" by creating a industry standard. The summer of 2020 i worked as an unskilled forestryworker-assistant - earning me 24$ hour. I was employed by a small (20 people) buisness where forestry wasn't their main operation. I was hired on the unions terms even thou only two people in the buiness had any relation to this field. 56 pages publicly avaible 2017-2020 w C086 Why Becuase if the company simply hired me on union terms they would sign off any scenario where i would complain or make fuss. Can you imagine a person on twitter having success on a complaining post when the rest of the nation that works in the same field imidiately responds to this is outlaying that the comlaining part demands stuff that no one else in the union gets or actually complains about (as you can extrapolate by the very fact this thing it's not in the unions agreement). The only looser in a unionized society is the shareholders - as they can't get filthy rich just as easy. Employees and employers alike benefit hugely from having unions. Don't believe the lies. Memes.
